questions.text: A 56 year old man brought to pulmonologist with complaints chronic cough & history of heavy smoking for 30 years. He was advised for bronchoscopy for suspected bronchogenic carcinoma. Before starting the intervention, the anesthesiologist administered a drug to prevent anxiety and to provide anterograde amnesia of the procedure as a part of pre-anaesthetic medication. Which of the following drugs would be most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
• Benzodiazepines like diazepam (5-10 mg oral) or lorazepam (2 mg oral or 0.05 mg/kg i.m. 1 hour before) have become popular drugs for pre-anaesthetic medication because they produce tranquility and smoothen induction.
  • There is loss of recall of perioperative events (especially with lorazepam) with little respiratory depression or accentuation of postoperative vomiting.
  • They counteract CNS toxicity of local anaesthetics and are being used along with fentanyl for a variety of minor surgical and endoscopic procedures.
  • Midazolam is a good amnesic with potent and shorter lasting action.

Option A, C & D: All other given options are not suitable choice for pre-anaesthetic medications

Key Takeaway

  • Diazepam or lorazepam have become popular drugs for pre-anaesthetic medication because they produce tranquility and smoothen induction.

[Good to Know]

[Diazepam]

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page number 413

questions.text: A 63 year old woman came to medicine outpatient department with complains of weakness and a tremor. On examination she has mask like facies and exhibits pill rolling with her fingers and muscle rigidity. Which of the following drugs would exacerbate her Parkinson's disease?
questions.solution:
• This patient is suffering from Parkinson's disease.
  • Chlorpromazine is a dopamine antagonist and will worsen the symptoms of Parkinson's disease.
  • In nonpsychotic individuals CPZ produces indifference to surroundings, paucity of thought, psychomotor slowing, emotional quietening, reduction in initiative and tendency to go off to sleep from which the subject is easily arousable.
  • Spontaneous movements are minimized but slurring of speech, ataxia or motor incoordination does not occur.
  • This is mostly perceived to be unpleasant, and has been referred to as the 'neuroleptic syndrome'.
  • The typical antipsychotic drugs have potent dopamine D2 receptor blocking property and produce extrapyramidal motor side effects. As such, they are called 'Neuroleptic drugs'.

Option A, B & D: All other given options are one way of another used for Parkinson disease.

Key Takeaway:

  • Chlorpromazine is a dopamine antagonist and will worsen the symptoms of Parkinson's disease.

[Must Know]

[Chlorpromazine]

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page number 464

questions.text: A 34 year old patient of schizophrenia taking anti-Psychotic drug haloperidol was brought to Psychiatry OPD with complaints of turning of neck to one side, excessive salivation, decreased body movements and tremors of hands. Which of the following adverse effect is the result of haloperidol therapy in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Extra Pyramidal syndrome is extremely common with the use of haloperidol. It is not dose related. The clinical picture resembles parkinsonian like syndrome.
  • Anti parkinsonian drug eg. Trihexiphenidyl is used to treat this disorder.

Extrapyramidal disturbances

  • These are the major dose-limiting side effects; more prominent with high potency drugs like fluphenazine, haloperidol, pimozide, etc., least with thioridazine, clozapine, and all other atypical antipsychotics, except higher dose of risperidone.

Key Takeaway:

  • Extrapyramidal disturbances are the major dose-limiting side effects; more prominent with high potency drugs like haloperidol

[Must Know]

[Haloperidol]

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page number 471

questions.text: A 45 year old male with history of having alcoholic cirrhosis is seen in the emergency because of a laceration of the scalp. Which of the following local anaesthetic agent would potentially be toxic in this patient, hence should be avoided?
questions.solution:
• Ester-type local anesthetics are mainly hydrolyzed by pseudocholinesterases.
  • Amide type local anesthetics are hydrolyzed by microsomal enzymes in the liver.
  • Of the listed agents, only lidocaine is an amide and can be influenced by liver dysfunction

Features of amide linked Local anaesthetics (compared to ester LAs)

  • Produce more intense and longer lasting anaesthesia
  • Bind to α1 acid glycoprotein in plasma
  • Not hydrolysed by plasma esterases
  • Rarely cause hypersensitivity reactions; no cross sensitivity with ester LAs
  • Ester-linked LAs (procaine, etc.) are rapidly hydrolysed by plasma pseudocholinesterase and the remaining by esterases in the liver.
  • Amide-linked LAs (lidocaine, etc.) are degraded only in the liver microsomes by dealkylation and hydrolysis.
  • Metabolism of lidocaine is hepatic blood-flow dependent.
  • The maximal safe dose of LAs is lower in patients with hepatic disease and in the elderly who have decreased liver function.

Key Takeaway:

  • Metabolism of lidocaine is hepatic blood-flow dependent, hence dose of lidocaine should be lowered in patients with hepatic disease and in the elderly who have decreased liver function.

[Good to Know]

[Lidocaine]

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page number 391-575

questions.text: An infant brought to paediatric department with complaints of abnormal penile curvature with opening of urethra below the penile shaft. He was having Hypospadias. Which of the following drug if taken during pregnancy leads to development of Hypospadias in the baby?
questions.solution:
The drugs that have been associated with high incidence of hypospadias include:

  • Valproic acid
  • Phenytoin
  • Progesterone (often given to mothers as part of IVF treatment)
  • Diethylstilbestrol
  • Clomiphene (used to induce ovulation during IVF treatment)

Teratogenic Drugs

Key Takeaway

  • Valproic acid is associated with Spina bifida and other neural tube defects, heart and limb abnormalities, Hypospadias in babies if taken during pregnancy.

[Good to Know]

[Valproic acid]

Reference: Goodman & Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics, 12th edition, page number 1846

questions.text: A 76 year old man was brought to the emergency department with complaints of pain in lower abdomen and not having passed urine since last 24 hours. The bladder was found to be full. His son informed that he was depressed for the last 2 years and only the day before a doctor had given him some medicine. Which of the following drug is most likely to have received by him?
questions.solution:
Adverse effects of TCAs

  • Anticholinergic: dry mouth, bad taste, constipation, epigastric distress, urinary retention (especially in males with enlarged prostate), blurred vision, palpitation.
  • Sedation, mental confusion and weakness, especially with amitriptyline and more sedative congeners.
  • Increased appetite and weight gain is noted with most TCAs
  • Sweating (despite antimuscarinic action) and fine tremors are relatively common.
  • Seizure threshold is lowered - fits may be precipitated, especially in children.
  • Postural hypotension, especially in older patients.
  • Sexual distress: especially delay or interference with erection, ejaculation and occasionally with orgasm.
  • Cardiac arrhythmias, especially in patients with ischaemic heart disease. Arrhythmias may be responsible for sudden death in these patients.
  • Rashes and jaundice due to hypersensitivity are rare.

Key Takeaway

  • Amitriptyline is associated with urinary retention (especially in males with enlarged prostate) due to its anti-cholinergic side effects

[Good to Know]

[Amitriptyline]

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page number 486-487

questions.text: A 38 year old female patient is on drug therapy for Bipolar disorder. She later came to her psychiatrist with complains of confusion, weight gain, tremors and has lost her sex drive. She also complains of excessive thirst and frequent urination while being on medication. Which of the following drug she is most likely prescribed?
questions.solution:
Adverse effects of Lithium

  • Nausea, vomiting and mild diarrhoea occur initially, can be minimized by starting at lower doses.
  • Thirst and polyuria are experienced by most patients
  • Fine tremors may occur even at therapeutic concentrations.
  • CNS toxicity manifests as plasma concentration rises producing coarse tremors, giddiness, ataxia, motor incoordination, nystagmus, mental confusion, slurred speech, hyper-reflexia

Lithium

  • It is a small monovalent cation that does not produce any acute effect but on prolonged use, acts as a mood stabilizer.

Effects of lithium

(Mnemonic = Lithium)

L - Leucocytes

I - Increased

T - Tremors (Most common side effect)

H - Hypothyroidism

I - Increased Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, can be used for the treatment of SIADH.

U - Increase Urine Amiloride is DOC for lithium induced DI.

M should be avoided in expectant Mothers as it causes Ebstein's anomaly

Key Takeaway:

  • It is a small monovalent cation that does not produce any acute effect but on prolonged use, acts as a mood stabilizer in bipolar mood disorder albeit with a lot of side effect requiring therapeutic drug monitoring

[Good to Know]

[Lithium]

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page number 475-476

questions.text: A 13 year old boy with severe asthma has been treated for 6 months. His parents now complain that he seems to be very fat around the face and shoulders, bruises easily and has discoloured streaks on his abdomen. Laboratory tests reveal moderate hyperglycemia. Which of the following drug he has probably been receiving?
questions.solution:
• This patient's presentation is typical of corticosteroid toxicity (iatrogenic Cushing syndrome).
  • Prednisone is an effective corticosteroid frequently used by mouth to control severe asthma that is not responsive to inhaled corticosteroids.
  • High doses of prednisone, given chronically, very predictably cause signs and symptoms of hypercorticism.

Cushing's habitus: characteristic appearance with

  • Rounded face
  • Narrow mouth
  • Supraclavicular hump
  • Obesity of trunk with relatively thin limbs

Fragile skin, purple striae-typically on thighs and lower abdomen with

  • Easy bruising
  • Telangiectasis
  • Hirsutism
  • Cutaneous atrophy

Key Takeaway:

  • High doses of prednisone, given chronically, very predictably cause signs and symptoms of hypercorticism.

Option A, C & D: Rest all agents given here are not associated with development of Cushing habitus.

[Must Know]

[Prednisone]

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page number 317

questions.text: A 60 year old diabetic male on an oral hypoglycemic agent develops abnormal liver function tests. Which of the following agent can cause this finding?
questions.solution:
• Hepatic dysfunction has occurred particularly with the use of Troglitazone, necessitating its removal from the market.
  • Patients treated with other thiazolidinediones should be monitored for this possibility.
  • Thiazolidinediones
    • Troglitazone, pioglitazone and rosiglitazone are the drugs in this group that act as agonists of a nuclear receptor; peroxisome proliferator activated receptor gamma (PPARγ).
  • It regulates the transcription of genes involved in glucose and lipid metabolism. Important genes that are up regulated by PPAR-γ are:
    • Adiponectin
    • Fatty acid transport protein
    • Insulin receptor substrate
    • GLUT - 4
    • These drugs are used to reverse insulin resistance in type II DM. These drugs also tend to increase HDL.
  • Troglitazone was withdrawn due to serious hepatotoxicity and monitoring of hepatic function is recommended for other glitazones also.
  • Glitazones have been reported to cause weight gain, edema and plasma volume expansion. Therefore, these should be avoided in CHF patients. (NYHA class III and IV).

Key Takeaway

  • Hepatic dysfunction has occurred particularly with the use of troglitazone, necessitating its removal from the market. Patients treated with other thiazolidinediones should be monitored for this possibility.

[Good to Know]

[Troglitazone]

Reference: Goodman & Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics, 14th edition, page number 1036

choices.text: Reduction in the release of cytokines, such as IL-1 and IL-2
Impairment of prostaglandin and leukotriene synthesis

questions.text: A 56 year old male patient was prescribed oral prednisone for rheumatoid arthritis for multiple reasons as glucocorticoids are powerful anti-inflammatory agents. Which of the following is not an anti-inflammatory mechanism of action of glucocorticoids pertaining to its anti-inflammatory effect?
questions.solution:
• Glucocorticoids actually increase the number of circulating neutrophils as inhibition of margination and migration occurs.
  • Paradoxically, this is an anti-inflammatory effect as neutrophils had not been reaching the sites where they were needed.
  • Inflammatory responses Irrespective of the type of injury or insult, the attending inflammatory response is suppressed by glucocorticoids.

This includes attenuation of following

  • Increased capillary permeability
  • Local exudation
  • Cellular infiltration
  • Phagocytic activity
  • Late responses like capillary proliferation, collagen deposition, fibroblastic activity and ultimately scar formation.

Glucocorticoids interfere at several steps in the inflammatory response but the most important overall mechanism appears to be limitation of recruitment of inflammatory cells at the local site and production of proinflammatory mediators like PGs, LTs, PAF through indirect inhibition of phospholipase A2.

Option A, B & D: All of the other choices are anti-inflammatory mechanisms of glucocorticoid action.

Key Takeaway

  • Glucocorticoids interfere at several steps in the inflammatory response but the most important overall mechanism appears to be limitation of recruitment of inflammatory cells at the local site and production of proinflammatory mediators like PGs, LTs, PAF through indirect inhibition of phospholipase A2.

[Must Know]

[Glucocorticoids]

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page number 310

questions.text: A 49 year old male patient with history of having type-II diabetes mellitus came to medicine outpatient department seeking treatment for his uncontrolled diabetes along with metformin alone. His physician has advised him an anti-hyperglycemic drug as add on to existing therapy. Which of the following drug does not cause hypoglycaemia?
questions.solution:
Acarbose as a monotherapy dose not cause hypoglycemia

Acarbose (α Glucosidase inhibitors)

  • It is a complex oligosaccharide which reversibly inhibits α-glucosidases, the final enzymes for the digestion of carbohydrates in the brush border of small intestine mucosa.
  • It slows down and decreases digestion and absorption of polysaccharides (starch, etc.) and sucrose.
  • In addition, GLP-1 release is promoted which may contribute to the effect.
  • Postprandial glycaemia is reduced without significant increase in insulin levels.
  • Regular use lowers HbA1c modestly (by 0.4-0.8%), but change in body weight and lipid levels is minimal.
  • Acarbose is a mild antihyperglycaemic and not a hypoglycaemic; may be used as an adjuvant to diet (with or without metformin/SU) in obese diabetics.
  • Flatulence, abdominal discomfort and loose stool are produced in about 50% patients due to fermentation of unabsorbed carbohydrates.
  • Patient acceptability of α-glucosidase inhibitors is poor due to uncomfortable g.i. symptoms.

Option A & B: Both can cause hypoglycaemia.

Option C: Nateglinide, a D-phenylalanine derivative, is the latest insulin secretagogue to become clinically available. Incidence of hypoglycaemia with nateglinide may be the lowest of all the secretagogues.

Key Takeaway

  • α glucosidase Inhibitors are acarbose, Voglibose and Miglitol which decrease carbohydrate absorption from the GIT.
  • Major adverse effect of these drugs is flatulence due to fermentation of unabsorbed carbohydrates. (therefore, contra-indicated in inflammatory bowel disease) These do not cause hypoglycemia.

[Must Know]

[Acarbose]

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page number 300-301

questions.text: Which of the following statement is least correct regarding use of Exenatide?
questions.solution:
• Exenatide is a synthetic DPP-4 resistant analogue which activates GLP-1 receptors and produces the same responses.
  • Injected subcutaneous before breakfast and dinner, it is used as add-on drug to metformin/Sulfonylurea in poorly controlled type 2 diabetics.

GLP-1 Receptor Agonists:

  • Exenatide and liraglutide are GLP-1 receptor agonists.
  • These are administered subcutaneously and act by mechanism similar to GLP-1
  • New drugs of this category, recently approved are albiglutide, semaglutide and dulaglutide.

Apart from releasing insulin, GLP-1 has following actions:

  • Suppresses glucagon secretion
  • Preserves islet cell integrity and decreases apoptosis.
  • Delays gastric emptying resulting in reduced appetite
  • Anorectic effect through CNS

GLP-1 has lower risk of causing hypoglycemia.

Exenatide therapy has shown to have multiple actions as following

  • Potentiation of glucose-mediated insulin secretion,
  • Suppression of postprandial glucagon release
  • Slowed gastric emptying,
  • Central loss of appetite.

Exenatide is injected subcutaneously within 60 minutes before a meal

The major adverse effects are nausea (about 44% of users) and vomiting and diarrhea.

Weight loss is reported in some users, presumably because of the nausea and anorectic effects.

A serious and, in some cases, fatal adverse effect of exenatide is necrotizing and hemorrhagic pancreatitis.

Key Takeaway

  • Exenatide is a synthetic DPP-4 resistant analogue which activates GLP-1 receptors and produces the same responses.
  • Injected s.c. before breakfast and dinner, it is used as add-on drug to metformin/SU in poorly controlled type 2 diabetics.

[Good to Know]

[Exenatide]

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page number 293

choices.text: Strong family history of breast cancer

questions.text: A 52 year old postmenopausal female patient has evidence of low bone mineral density on DEXA scan. Her physician is considering pharmacotherapy with Raloxifene. Which of the following characteristics of this patient is most likely to lead her physician to select Raloxifene?
questions.solution:
• Raloxifene has antiestrogen effects on breast and uterine tissue but estrogenic effects on bone and it is used to prevent osteoporosis.
  • It is not used to treat breast cancer, menopausal symptoms or endometriosis, or for contraception.

Raloxifene

  • It is an estrogen partial agonist in bone, on lipid metabolism and cardiovascular system, but an antagonist in endometrium and breast.
  • Follow up studies have shown that raloxifene reduces the risk of breast cancer by 65%, though the protection was confined to ER-positive breast cancer.
  • Raloxifene does not stimulate endometrial proliferation and there is no increase in the risk of endometrial carcinoma.

Uses of Raloxifene

  • Raloxifene is a second line drug for prevention and treatment of osteoporosis in postmenopausal women; Ca2+ and vit D supplements enhance the benefit.
  • It is also approved for prevention of breast cancer in women with risk factors.

Key Takeaway

  • Raloxifene has antiestrogen effects on breast and uterine tissue but estrogenic effects on bone, and it is used to prevent osteoporosis

[Good to Know]

[Raloxifene]

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page number 338-339

questions.text: A 56 year old male patient presented to medicine department with coarse facial features, abnormally large hands, feets & jaw, deepened voice with large tongue. Later he was diagnosed as having Acromegaly. Which of the following parenteral drug effective for the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
• Dopamine agonists like bromocriptine and cabergoline are the only oral drugs for acromegaly.
  • Octreotide and pegvisomant are injectable drugs for acromegaly.

Pegvisomant

  • Pegvisomant is a Growth hormone receptor antagonist approved for the treatment of acromegaly.
  • Pegvisomant binds to the Growth hormone receptor but does not activate JAK-STAT signaling or stimulate IGF-1 secretion.

Option A & B: Dopamine agonists like bromocriptine and cabergoline are the only oral drugs for acromegaly.

Option D: Main indication of thyroid hormones is hypothyroidism (cretinism, myxedema and myxedema coma). Levo-thyroxine (T4) is preferred for all these indications

Key Takeaway

  • Octreotide and pegvisomant are injectable drugs for acromegaly.

[Must Know]

[Pegvisomant]

Reference: Goodman & Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics, 13th edition, page number:777

questions.text: A 39 year old female diagnosed with Graves disease was on medication for the same throughout the pregnancy. She delivered a child with Scalp defects as congenital anomaly. Which of the following drug is most likely implicated for this teratogenic effect?
questions.solution:
• All Antithyroid drugs (carbimazole, methimazole, propylthiouracil) if taken during pregnancy can cause Fetal hypothyroidism, congenital goiter, scalp defects (aplasia cutis congenita)

Use of antithyroid drugs in pregnancy may result in following side effects:

  • Fetal hypothyroidism
  • Aplasia cutis
  • Scalp or patchy hair defect
  • Choanal atresia
  • Esophageal atresia
  • Tracheo-esophageal fistula
  • Minor facial anomalies
  • Hypoplastic or absent phalanges
  • Psychomotor delay

Key Takeaway

  • All Antithyroid drugs (carbimazole, methimazole, propylthiouracil) if taken during pregnancy can cause Fetal hypothyroidism, congenital goiter, scalp defects (aplasia cutis congenita)

[Must Know]

[Carbimazole]

Reference: Goodman & Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics, 13th edition, page number 797
